body:
Hmm while working on fixing PR, I have noticed that you have written tests for similar test-case (as mentioned in the original issue), but it targets the `tmpdir`fixture. I tested its behavior and it seems really to work as expected, therefore the bug is present only for the `tmp_path` fixture.

I will provide test coverage for this test case as part of the fix.

https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/commit/fc61bdd9073d86819eb54c8603384a10c626a9d4 had it "fixed" and https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/4427 also broke it again

@nicoddemus do you recall the exact platform issue?

actually https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/pull/4427/commits/5f1d69207260297738ff4dd96687fe049d2963a3 is a bad test that i wrote missunderstanding the situation

i believe we need to use abspath on windows and resolve on any unix

See the PR #4654.

Don't you think that `resolve()` will solve this for Windows? I unfortunately don't have way to test it.
@AuHau i recall resolve breaking on windows - @nicoddemus proposed just using abspath, and then i made a mistake with the osx tests

issue.title: Fix issue where working dir becomes wrong on subst drive on Windows. Fixes #5965

repository.name: pytest
repository.description: The pytest framework makes it easy to write small tests, yet scales to support complex functional testing

issue.body:
Note that I didn't change all the `Path.resolve()` occurrences on `pytest`, only the ones related to getting the current directory.

Fix #5965
Fix #7333
Close #6733
